item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“Avalon, post:16, topic:280436”]One thing that’s wrong here:

String[] test = {"what", "no", "yes"};
for(String array : test) {
          System.out.println(test);
     }
 }

You need to print out the elements, not the array itself.

I think more detail needs to be added as well.[/quote]

You’re right, my mistake. And I know.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @si_force Si Force
item.description:
@si_force wrote:

This is a bit similar to C++ I noticed, a bit;

[code]
// Example array.
#include
using namespace std;

int soul [] = {16, 2, 77, 40, 12071};
int n, result=0;

int main ()
{
for ( n=0 ; n<5 ; n++ )
{
result += soul[n];
}
cout << result;
return 0;
}[/code]

That would just be me noticing it though, not sure if anybody else did.

@Avalon wrote:

One thing that’s wrong here:

String[] test = {"what", "no", "yes"};
for(String array : test) {
          System.out.println(test);
     }
 }

You need to print out the elements, not the array itself.

I think more detail needs to be added as well.

item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @Ensure Ensure_
item.description:
@Ensure wrote:

Let's say you have the main method:

public static void main(String[] args) {

Every body’s server has the main method because it’s automatically executed upon initialization of the class file. From there, there will most likely be a method that’s called upon that which contains constructor statements to create new objects or classes.

i++ // this means that 'i' will increment.

It is an increment but rather a post increment if you’d like to get into specifics.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“The Soul, post:8, topic:280436”][quote author=jc22493 link=topic=370433.msg2800749#msg2800749 date=1243369973]

You missed a bracket on an example, also you are not properly looping through arrays.

Should be;

[code] public static void main(String[] args) {
int[] soul = {
5, 9, 6
};
int find = 9;
boolean isFound = false;

	for (int i : soul) {
		if (find == i) {
			isFound = true;
			break;
		}
	}
	System.out.println(isFound ? "Number: " + find : "Could not find " + find + " within the array.");
}[/code]

You can either use the for or for-each loop when looping through arrays, it really doesn’t matter.

Edit: Conventions fixed and tutorial edited.

Well, aren’t for-each loops a bit more efficient?

With a for-each loop, each individual iteration only requires one movement of the loop, because it starts from the prior integer.

If you had a list of 500 integers, and you used a for loop to iterate through it, each individual iteration will begin at the first integer, and loop to the one sought. When you need to iterate to 500, it will begin at 1, then loop all the way to 500.
[/quote]

That’s why I added it to my tutorial.[/quote]
Just trying to explain that it does matter whether you use a for loop or a for-each loop.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

Conventions fix’d.

I replaced the ‘if (isFound)’ bits with the ? operator :).

The purpose of the tutorial is to learn about the for loop, and several examples of its purpose.

Simple for statement:

for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) { System.out.println("Number: " + i); }

If you were to run this, it would print out ‘Number: 0-9’ in the command prompt.

int i = 0; // this is the declaration of this integer. We're using 'i' as the iterator because it's short and simple. You can use anything you want.
i < 10; // this means that if 'i' were to be greater than 10, the loop will conclude.
i++ // this means that 'i' will increment.

An example of the for loop in private servers would be for what you all probably know as the ‘master’ command.

Instead of having 25 or so lines for a command, you can shorten it to about 4.

if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("master") { for (int i = 0; i < 24; i++) { addSkillXP(Integer.MAX_VALUE, i); // using the MAX_VALUE constant of the Integer class, and using 'i' as the amount of skills you want to increase. } }

These for loops can also be used to loop through arrays.

Let’s say you have the main method:

public static void main(String[] args) {

You add this array:

int[] soul = {5, 9, 6};

And you declare this integer

int find = 9;

Also declare this boolean:

boolean isFound = false;

You can use the ‘find’ integer to find ‘9’ inside the ‘soul’ array.

public static void main(String[] args) { for (int i = 0; i < soul.length; i++) { if (soul[i] == find) { isFound = true; break; } } }

int i = 0 // declaration of the 'i' iterator
i < soul.length // loop will terminate if it's false
i++ // loop will increment
soul[i] == find // looks for the number 9 of the 'soul' array
isFound = true; // it's true because it has found the number 9
break; // if it's found, it ends the loop

You can add this if-then-else statement so that if it did indeed find ‘9’ in the array, it will print the number. If not, it will print that ‘9’ could not be found.

System.out.println(isFound ? "Number: " + find : "Could not find "+find+" within the array.");

Final version:

[code]public static void main(String[] args) {
int[] soul = {5, 9, 6};
int find = 9;
boolean isFound = false;

for (int i = 0; i < soul.length; i++) {
	if (soul[i] == find) {
		isFound = true;
		break;
	}
}
System.out.println(isFound ? "Number: " + find : "Could not find "+find+" within the array.");

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Using the for/enhanced for loop
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

The purpose of the tutorial is to learn about the for loop, and some examples of how it works.

Simple for statement:

for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) { System.out.println("Number: " + i) ; }

If you were to run this, it would print out ‘Number: 0-9’ in the command prompt.

This is the declaration of this integer. We’re using ‘i’ as the iterator because it’s short and easy:

int i = 0;

This means that if ‘b’ were to be greater than 10, the loop will conclude. All this does is basically check if ‘i’, the iterator is less than 10, and if it is, the loop will continue:

i < 10;

All the below means is ‘i’ will go up by 1 until it reaches 10.

i++

An example of the for loop in private servers would be for what you all probably know as the ‘master’ command. Instead of having 25 or so lines for a command, you can shorten it to about 4:

if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("master") { for (int i = 0; i < 24; i++) { addSkillXP(Integer.MAX_VALUE, b) ; // using the MAX_VALUE constant of the Integer class, and using 'b' as the amount of skills you want to increase. } }

These for loops can also be used to loop through arrays.

For example, you can make it so it loops through an array of Strings to check if the user is typing something within that array, and if so, it won’t send the message.

if(command.equals("yell")) { String[] array = {"abc", "dfg", "hij"}; String msg = command.substring(5); for(int i = 0; i < array.length; i++) { if(msg.contains(i)) return; yell(playerName+": "+msg); }

Or you could use the for each loop, also known as the enhanced for loop.

if(command.equals("yell")) { String[] array = {"abc", "dfg", "hij"}; String msg = command.substring(5); for(String elements : array) { if(msg.contains(elements)) return; yell(playerName+": "+msg); }

The for each loop is great for grabbing every element in an array. It is also faster than the for loop.

Read full topic
